data.title: CentOS fails to launch any terminal by default
data.body:
Testing #5463

CentOS comes with `gnome-terminal` installed, yet Code fails to launch it. It fails to launch any terminal, actually.

[This detection](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/workbench/parts/execution/electron-browser/terminal.ts#L9) might be too overzealous.

Here's the reason:

```
[joao@localhost]~% echo $DESKTOP_SESSION 
gnome-classic
```

data.title: Debug: Show debug state in activity bar?

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
We are not that aggressive anymore in opening the debug viewlet when you hit a breakpoint. Why not show the debug states as decoration on the debug viewlet itself? I could imagine a yellow pause icon when you are on a breakpoint and the green play icon when you are actually running or debugging a program.

@stevencl @chrisdias @bgashler1 thoughts?

data.title: Reinstallation of Code Alpha left it in a bad state
data.body:
Fixing #5463

I had Code Alpha installed in CentOS (red hat). Today, I downloaded the latest RPM, installed it and now I can't launch Code nor reinstall it.

It doesn't seem to be installed at all. It is also gone from the Applications menu, where it used to be before installing it today.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/22350/14820319/7067f6b8-0bc6-11e6-92cd-b2c4bae2a2c1.png)

data.title: I am sometimes loosing output for git in the output panel
data.body:
I am seeing this from time to time that I run a git operation that fails and then when I want to show output I do not see the git output. Even when I explicitly refresh git viewlet where more output should show up (e.g. "fetch...") no more output is added.

I do not have steps to reproduce and a refresh typically fixes it but wanted to report it if others hit this?

data.title: 'Show active file in explorer' should be 'Reveal active file in explorer'
data.body:
#5329

I believe 'Reveal active file in explorer' is a better name because it revealse the file and this name is more connected to the setting name `explorer.autoReveal`

I for instance needed some time to find the corresponding action in the command pallete because I was looking for **reveal**.

data.title: Debug: continue action seems broken for Go extension
data.body:
Testing #5644
### Setup

It's easier to install the whole thing in Linux:
- [Install Go 1.6](https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/how-to-install-go-1-6-on-ubuntu-14-04)
- [Setup Go](https://golang.org/doc/code.html#GOPATH)
- [Install and setup the go extension](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=lukehoban.Go)
- Install gin: `go get github.com/gin-gonic/gin`
### Repro

Create a new folder. In it, create a `server.go` file with the following contents:

``` go
package main

import "github.com/gin-gonic/gin"

func main() {
    r := gin.Default()
    r.GET("/ping", func(c *gin.Context) {
        c.JSON(200, gin.H{
            "message": "pong",
        })
    })
    r.Run() // listen and server on 0.0.0.0:8080
}
```

Set the debugger config: `"program": "${workspaceRoot}/server.go"`.
### Repro
- Set breakpoint on line 8.
- Start debug.
- Run `curl http://localhost:8080/ping` to hit the breakpoint.
- Press `Continue`

The debugger continues but the UI fails to update that it did continue. This is broken on latest Alpha but not on stable 1.0.0.

data.title: [css] Fixed slightly misleading description of all CSS margin properties
data.body:
Negative values are allowed in the following CSS properties:

```
margin
margin-top
margin-right
margin-bottom
margin-left
```

[See this relevant W3C document](https://www.w3.org/TR/CSS2/box.html#margin-properties)

> "Negative values for margin properties are allowed"

I believe it is slightly misleading to state that '"The values may not be negative" when negative values are accepted and valid CSS.

![screen shot 2016-04-26 at 13 15 15](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1794099/14817969/b62a2cd6-0bba-11e6-9630-b9a0f03186f5.png)

data.title: debug - don't use uuid to generate tree element ids
data.body: I have profiled the Debug Console when under heavy load and one thing that stands out is usage of `uuid` in the [`OutputElement`](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/workbench/parts/debug/common/debugModel.ts#L158). Generating UUIDs (which consist of 32 random numbers) is overkill for this problem and a simple static counter should be enough.
